Graphical abstract γ-Lactam derivatives are widespread biologically active compounds, covering a large range of activities. Following our interest in both medicinal and green chemistries, we developed an original, cesium salts-mediated, scalable and solvent-free methodology to transform biosourced pyroglutamic acid and its derivatives to their N,N′-aminals, N,O,N,S-acetals and C5-substituted γ-lactams in good to excellent yields. This protocol is applicable to a large range of substrates, conducting to C5-substituted γ-lactam derivatives as potential new biologically active compounds. Keywords Cesium Catalysis Pterolactam Solvent-free Amidoalkylation 1 Introduction The γ-lactam known as pyrrolidin-2-one is a heterocyclic moiety presents in a large number of natural and unnatural compounds [1–3] covering a large number of biological activities such as anti-inflammatory [4], antitumoral [5], anti-tuberculosis [6], agents in respiratory disorders and asthma [7,8], active substances in neurodegenerative diseases [9,10] or analgesics [11].As bacterial resistance towards the classical β-lactams is continuously developing, the antibiotics drugs research has been focusing on alternatives. Among them, γ-lactams and their analogues have been spotlighted, highlighting the need for synthetic pathways to such compounds [12–16]. A large range of synthetic strategies is available to build up the γ-lactam ring [17]. However, in the frame of green chemistry, the valorization of pyroglutamic acid 1, a natural amino acid derivative, sounds of greater interest for proposing new γ-lactam derivatives. As a consequence numerous strategies have been applied to modify this biosourced resource [18–22]. Biologically occurring or active compounds have been reported, based on cyclic N,N′-aminals or N,O-acetals, such as compound A, filed as potent antidepressive agent [23], lactam B as a kynurenine-3-monooxygenase inhibitor [24], 2,4-pyrrolidine dione C as fungicide [25], heterocycle D as sodium channel blocker [26], Sessiline extracted from Acanthopanax sessiliflorus [27], or compound E as anti-cancer drug [28]. Following our interest in biologically active compounds, our current work focused on the modification of pyroglutamic acid 1 (Fig. 1 and Scheme 1 ). Even if some works deal with the formation of 5-aminopyrrolidin-2-one motif from pyroglutamic acid 1 (Scheme 1), there is a clear lack of a general methodology for creating cyclic N,N′-aminals from 1, without any protection nor activation of the lactam, and easier than the Curtius rearrangement of pyroglutamic acid [29]. One of the available strategies relies on the use of pterolactam 3, readily available from pyroglutamic acid in high yield and purity [30]. The reaction of pterolactam 3 is mainly reported under acidic conditions. Recently, we reported a new methodology, relying on the use of a triflic acid catalyzed intermolecular α-amination of pterolactams via N-acyliminium species to produce 5-arylamino pyrrolidinones [30]. However the scope of this reaction to other nitrogen or oxygenated nucleophiles is highly limited. In fact, this acidic protocol gave good yields with anilines but failed when using benzyl amine, phenylhydrazine or benzyl alcohol derivatives. As a consequence, an original methodology to improve the reactivity of pterolactam 3 with a large range of nucleophiles has been developed under mild non-acidic conditions (Scheme 1). 2 Experimental 2.1 General informations Starting materials are commercially available and were used without further purification. Melting points were measured on a MPA 100 OptiMelt® apparatus. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were acquired at 400 MHz for 1H NMR, 100 MHz for 13C NMR and 376 MHz for 19F NMR on a Varian 400-MR spectrometer, at 25 °C. Chemical shifts (δ) are quoted in parts per million (ppm) and are referenced to TMS as an internal standard. Coupling constants (J) are quoted in hertz. Comparisons with known or reported compounds and 2D methods (HMBC and HSQC experiments) have been used to confirm the NMR peak assignments. Organic solutions have been concentrated under reduced pressure using a Büchi rotary evaporator. Column chromatography was performed with a CombiFlash Rf Companion (Teledyne-Isco System) using RediSep packed columns. IR spectra were recorded on a Varian 640-IR FT-IR Spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) of new compounds were determined on a Thermo Electron apparatus by ‘Pôle Chimie Moléculaire-Welience’, Faculté de Sciences Mirande, Université de Bourgogne, Dijon, France. Yield refers to the isolated analytically pure material. 2.2 General procedure for the synthesis of pterolactam 3 A mixture of pyroglutamic acid 1 (5.16 g, 0.04 mol) and 30% sodium methoxide in methanol (1.15 g) in methanol (500 mL) was placed in a beaker equipped with 6 graphite-rods anodes and 6 graphite-rods cathodes and a stirring bar. The carbon rods, immersed 100 mm into the solution were spaced 10 mm apart. During the electrolysis, the temperature of the reaction mixture was maintained at 15 °C by using a water bath. The current intensity was fixed at 0.5 amperes, and the cell voltage was initially 5.4 volts. The electrolysis was performed for 6 h. A white precipitate is filtered and discarded. The filtrate is evaporated and then dichloromethane (40 mL) is added, followed by acidified water (pH = 5). The organic phase is separated and the aqueous phase is acidified by citric acid and extracted by dichloromethane. The organic phases are combined and evaporated at 50 °C under vacuum. The oily crude product obtained rapidly crystallized into white pure pterolactam 3 in quantitative yield. 2.3 General procedure for the synthesis of products 4-44 To a mixture of 5-methoxypyrolidone 3 (17.4 mmol, 1 eq) and CsF (0.086 mmol, 5 mol%) was added the nucleophilic reactant (17.4 mmol, 1 eq). The mixture was stirred under moderate vacuum (30 mmHg) at 80 °C, until the NMR conversion showed no more progression or after caking of the medium. Then, the crude product was precipitated by Et2O and recrystallized from EtOH or purified by flash liquid chromatography (silica gel, gradient of ethyl acetate in n-heptane), to afford the target compounds. All products 4-44 were identified by comparing their spectral date with those of authentic samples or by elemental analysis for new compounds. 2.4 Protocol for the recording of pH 45 g of pterolactam 3 (0.395 mol) was dissolved in 20 mL of water and heated under low stirring at 80 °C. The pH was recorded thanks a combined electrode (calomel reference) which was calibrated just before the set of experiments. The pH was recorded every minute for 15 min as soon as the cesium salt (CsF or Cs2CO3, 5 mol%) was added in the solution at 80 °C under stirring (200 rpm) (see Graph in SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 3.1Preliminary screening Pterolactam 3 was prepared in quantitative yield by electrochemical decarboxylation of pyroglutamic acid as described by our group after slight modifications of literature process [30], and used as substrate model with benzyl amine and furfuryl alcohol as nucleophiles. In a first approach, various catalysts, reported as active for related reactions were screened to promote the reaction (Table 1 ). At first, furfuryl alcohol was used as oxygenated nucleophile. Without any solvent nor catalyst, the conversion is low and only an 11% yield of the target compound 4 is obtained (Table 1, entry 1). Acids, known to favor iminium salts formation, were then attempted as catalysts (Table 1, entries 2-5). Methanesulfonic acid, Amberlyst H15 resin or Lewis acids led to a total degradation of pterolactam 3 (Table 1, entries 2-5). As a consequence, some basic promoters were attempted. Triethylamine did not lead to any conversion nor degradation (Table 1, entry 6). Interestingly, addition of cesium carbonate led to a complete conversion of pterolactam 3 and the target compound 4 was obtained for the first time while in a low 17% yield (Table 1, entry 7). This encouraging result highlighted the role of a base during the course of the reaction. Less basic cesium salts were then used with good results (Table 1, entries 8–10). Addition of CsF as catalyst proved to decrease conversion but favored the formation of the target product 4 (Table 1, entry 8). Among halogenated anions, fluoride proved to be the most potent, maybe due to the solvatation of the salt in the medium, or to the difference in ion-pairing with the cesium cation [31] (Table 1, entries 9–11). Increasing the time of reaction proved to be more beneficial than increasing the load of CsF (Table 1, entries 12-13).Elimination of neoformed methanol under moderate vacuum (30 mmHg) allowed to avoid the reversibility of the reaction and increased the yield of 4 to 58%, even with a 5 mol% load of CsF (Table 1, entry 14). As a consequence, the screening of the catalysts for benzyl amine as nucleophile was realized solvent-free at a 5 mol% catalyst load. Globally, benzyl amine reacted similarly to furfuryl alcohol except in presence of cesium carbonate. Cesium fluoride is the most active catalyst, and compound 5is obtained in 57% yield (Table 1, entries 15–19) [29a]. Cesium carbonate led to 92% yield and conversion, without any degradation (Table 1, entry 19). This confirmed the role of the base during the course of the reaction and a dramatical difference between alcohol and amine nucleophiles. Potassium salts led to lower results (Table 1, entry 21–22). Using TBAF hydrate as fluoride provider proved to be a good alternative to CsF (Table 1, entry 23). Addition of water as solvent decreased the rate of reaction and conducted to the formation of 5-hydroxypyrrolidin-2-one 2 as side product (3%)along with the desired product (32%) (Table 1, entry 24). The optimized neat protocol was then successfully applied in a larger scale (40 g of pterolactam) (Table 1, entries 25–26). The time of reaction was extended to overnight and was realized under mechanical stirring to ensure the completion of the reaction. In such conditions, target compounds 4 and 5 were obtained in 84% and 92% yield, respectively, showing the scalability of the process. 3.2 Mechanism of the reaction Cs2CO3 and CsF emerged as leading catalysts for the reaction of pterolactam 3in neat conditions. Among all non-radioactive elements, cesium has the lowest electronegativity and fluorine the highest electronegativity. So, CsF is highly dissociated, moderately basic and proved to be the most reactive source of fluoride anion compared with other salts [31]. Hence, the low nucleophilicity of the fluoride ion makes it as a useful base in several organic transformations [32]. Additional experiments were carried out to elucidate the mechanism of the reaction. Firstly, the pH of a melted solution of pterolactam 3 at 20 M in water at 80 °C was measured at 7.15. When 5 mol% of CsF is added the pH increased gradually to 9.0 (Fig. 2 ). In the same conditions, addition of 5 mol% of Cs2CO3 led to a final pH = 10.7. These data underlined the role of cesium salts as base. When benzylamine is added to the previously recorded solution of pterolactam at 80 °C, product 5 is obtained as expected.Secondly, the reaction was carried out in presence of an equimolar mixture of KF and CsF. As KF smoothly reacts with HF to create insoluble KHF2 the yield was expected to decrease if HF mediated the reaction. As the reaction in presence of KF + CsF gave slightly similar yields (66% with KF + CsF versus 65% with CsF alone), a non-acidic mediated catalysis was favored. Moreover 1H, 13C and 19F NMR spectra of pterolactam 3 in presence of CsF or Cs2CO3 were recorded at 80 °C and are identical, suggesting that the intermediates are similar. 19F NMR spectra of pterolactam 3 in presence of CsF did not exhibit any peak which could be attributed to free HF or to any C5-fluorinated intermediate. From all these data, a putative mechanism can be proposed. The catalytic role of cesium salts could occur via a 6-membered ring pathway involving cation-σ interactions between the salt and the pair of electrons from the oxygen atom, allowing the anion to free and act as a base, giving 3,4-dihydro-[2H]-pyrrol-2-one as intermediate (Scheme 2 ). This imine intermediate then suffers a nucleophilic attack leading to the pyrrolidine-2-one derivatives 4-44. Cesium salts are recovered and methanol is obtained as side product, which can be continuously eliminated. To design the most general methodology, other nucleophiles were screened at 80 °C during three hours in presence of the two pre-selected catalysts (CsF and Cs2CO3) (Fig. 3 ). Samples were analyzed after 1, 2 and 3 h. When using CsF at 5 mol%, all target compounds were observed in various yields, correlated both to time and nucleophilicity of the reactant. However, considering Cs2CO3 as catalyst, various behaviors were noted. On the one hand, substrates like 4-chloroaniline, phenylhydrazine, benzylamine and benzene sulfonylhydrazide (yellow, grey, red and green in Fig. 3) proved to react smoothly in excellent yields and short time of reaction. On the other hand, some compounds (benzyl alcohol, thiobenzamide) led to a complete degradation of the substrates and products after 3 h of heating. Benzoylhydrazide and 1-hydroxybenzotriazole led to lower conversions and yields with Cs2CO3 than with CsF. Noteworthy substrates known as good nucleophiles reacted better in these conditions than substrates with lower nucleophilicity. The behavior of the substrate in presence of Cs2CO3beingunpredictable, CsF was selected as catalyst for the development of our methodology. A large range of nitrogen nucleophiles was then submitted to the optimized conditions (Table 2 ). Aliphatic amines such as 2-phenethylamine reacted smoothly and 5-(phenethylamino)pyrrolidin-2-one [6] was isolated in 68% yield. Morpholine, as secondary aliphatic cyclic amine was successfully submitted to the reaction and gave product 7 [29a] in a satisfactory 70% yield. 4-Phenylpiperazine reacted well and gave the desired compound 8 [23] in 95% yield. In a similar way, a lipophilic amine such as decan-1-amine reacted well under such conditions, proving the applicability of the methodology. To our delight, aniline, known as a moderate nucleophile, reacted smoothly under such conditions, giving a quantitative conversion and 88% yield to product 10 [29a] after 5 h. Using 4-fluoroaniline gave similar results leading to 5-((4-fluorophenyl)amino)pyrrolidin-2-one [11] after only 2 h of reaction with a 82% isolated yield. When 4-aminophenol is used as substrate, the reaction proved to be highly selective and only N,N-aminal is formed, furnishing 5-((4-hydroxyphenyl)amino)pyrrolidin-2-one [12] in a satisfactory 50% yield. The same selectivity is also observed between phenylamino and benzamide groups, and 2-aminobenzamide reacted only thanks to the aniline moiety to give exclusively 2-((5-oxo pyrrolidin-2-yl)amino)benzamide [13] quantitatively. Heterocyclic amines such as 2-aminopyridine and 4,6-dimethyl-1,3,5-triazin-2-amine reacted also smoothly from the amino group under such conditions, producing the desired γ-lactams 15 and 16 in good 60% and 51% yields, respectively. Phenylhydrazine and 4-trifluoromethylhydrazine gave the desired products 17 and 18 in moderate to good yields. In such case the reaction occurred selectively on the primary amino group. 1-Methyl-1-phenylhydrazine was quantitatively transformed to its pyrrolidin-2-one derivative 19. Complete conversion and a very good 75% yield was obtained with 2-hydrazinylpyridine as nucleophile. Good conversion and a 60% isolated yield were observed for the reaction of 4-methylbenzenesulfonamide with pterolactam 3. However, a poor conversion is observed when using benzamide as substrate. This could be attributed to the low nucleophilicity of benzamide. Even if efforts have been dedicated to this transformation, no product could be isolated from the reaction medium. Moreover, the use of cesium carbonate as an alternate catalyst did not lead to better result. For similar reasons and with no surprise, no conversion was observed for the reaction of phenylurea with 3. On the contrary, phenylthiourea reacted very well via the nitrogen atom and 1-(5-oxopyrrolidin-2-yl)-3-phenylthiourea [24] was isolated in 60% yield. This behavior is different from that of thiobenzamide which reacted by the sulfur. Other nucleophilic substrates such as benzoylhydrazide or benzene sulfonylhydrazide were successfully submitted to the optimized conditions and gave the desired compounds 25 and 26 in excellent yields. Very acidic lactams able to furnish an anion under these conditions, like indoline-2,3-dione or thiazolidine-2,4-dione led to the desired products 27 and 28 in good yields. Globally, the optimized solvent-free conditions are widely applicable for the reaction of pterolactam 3 with a large range of nitrogen nucleophiles. The reactivity seems correlated as well to the nucleophilicity: the better nucleophile, the higher yield. As a consequence, other nucleophilic substrates were submitted to the optimized protocol (Table 3 ). Alcohols were then used as nucleophiles for the reaction with pterolactam 3. As expected, benzyl alcohol derivatives, known as moderate nucleophiles, gave moderate conversions and yields, in accordance with their lower nucleophilicity than those of benzyl amine (Table 3, compounds 29-32) [33]. Phenol and vanillin reacted not well in such conditions, in accordance with their low nucleophilicity. This lack of reactivity underlined the fact that no free anion formation occurred during the reaction. As a consequence, when 5-(hydroxymethyl)-2-methoxy-phenol is used as reactant, the primary alcohol selectively reacted with pterolactam 3 to give 5-((3-hydroxy-4-methoxybenzyl)oxy)pyrrolidin-2-one [32] as sole product. Primary alcohol such as phenethyl alcohol and 2-phenylethanol reacted in similar yields as benzyl alcohol leading to N,O-acetals 35 and 36 in 12% and 53% yields, respectively. The hindrance of the alcohol slightly impacted the yield, as benzydrol, a secondary alcohol, gave lower results than benzyl alcohol. On the whole, oxygenated nucleophiles moderately reacted under such conditions to give desired products 4 and 29-37 in low to moderate yields. Thiophenol reacted better than phenol under the same conditions, leading to 5-(phenylthio)pyrrolidin-2-one in 30% yield. When thiobenzamide was used as nucleophile, the conversion was moderate and a sole product was isolated, being exclusively linked by the sulfur atom. 5-Oxopyrrolidin-2-yl-benzimido thioate is obtained in 55% yield. The small difference in electronegativity between C and S and the larger size of S allows greater charge transfer from N to S in benzothioamide compared to benzamide. The resulting 5 Debye dipole moment is higher than in benzamide and favors S-alkylation [34]. N-Hydroxy-N-phenylbenzamide was submitted to the optimized conditions and led to the desired product 40 in moderate yield (20%, Table 3). 1-Hydroxybenzotriazole reacted smoothly, conducting to compound 41 in excellent conversion and yield after only four hours. Various polyfunctionalized compounds were also submitted to the optimized CsF-mediated protocol and gave the desired compounds 42-44 as C5-substituted γ-lactam in good to quantitative yields. As expected from the classical reactivity of enamine derivatives (Z)-methyl 3-aminobut-2-enoate gave product 42 in a moderate 50% yield [34]. Interestingly, N,N-dimethylamino uracile reacted exclusively via the methylene group to give compound 43 as the sole product in quantitative yield, underlining the high reactivity of such substrate under solvent-free cesium mediated reaction. Considering these three polyfunctionalized substrates, elected to study the selectivity of the reaction, it is notable that C5-substituted γ-lactams are preferentially formed compared with N,N-aminals or N,O-acetals under such cesium-catalyzed optimized conditions. Dimethylmalonate or dimedone also reacted smoothly under the optimized protocol, giving compounds 45 and 46 in good to very good yields, illustrating the applicability of this method for the production of C5-substituted γ-lactam. Moreover, bulky substrates reacted well under the optimized conditions (Table 3, Compounds 37, 40, 44), proving the interest of the designed protocol. Finally, the optimized protocol was applied to various substrates. On the one hand, it is notable that different leaving groups can be used instead of the methoxy one. Indeed, good results are obtained with primary or bulky alcohols (Table 4 , entries 1-2). The yields are moderate, being limited by the competition between aniline and neo-formed alcohol as nucleophiles. Aniline is also able to displace a bulky N-hydroxy leaving group in good yield (Table 4, entry 3). Thiophenol also acts as good leaving group in presence of aniline (Table 4, entry 4). On the opposite, aniline can be replaced by benzylamine in such conditions in moderate yield (Table 4, entry 5). To summarize, various leaving groups can be successfully used under the optimized CsF-mediated methodology. 3-Methoxyisoindolin-1-one also proved to be a good substrate for the reaction with benzylamine (Table 4, entry 7) and product 47 is obtained in 61% yield with a total conversion. Vinylogues of the pyrolidin-2-one ring have also been successfully submitted to the CsF-catalyzed transformation in presence of 4-nitroaniline in very good conversion and yields (Table 4, entries 7-8). These results proved the large range of applicability of the CsF-mediated protocol. 4 Conclusion A simple, clean, scalable, widely applicable, CsF-mediated protocol for the formation of N,N′-aminals, N,O, N,S-acetals or C5-substituted γ-lactams has been optimized under solvent-free conditions. Among all tested catalysts, cesium salts have retained our attention thanks to their reported abilities to shorten reaction time, increase yields and allow mild reaction conditions and easy final work-up procedures. Due to all these advantages the use of cesium salts has reached the industrial acceptance. This sustainable and easily scalable protocol led to the formation of various γ-lactams from biosourced pterolactam 3. This protocol has been realized in equimolar conditions of pterolactam 3 and nucleophiles but, for specific substrates, yields and rates could be improved by using an excess of nucleophiles or shifting from CsF to Cs2CO3. In our continuous interest in medicinal chemistry, these new products will be tested as potential antibiotics. Acknowledgements Authors gratefully acknowledge Pr A. coredata.dc:description: γ-Lactam derivatives are widespread biologically active compounds, covering a large range of activities. Following our interest in both medicinal and green chemistries, we developed an original, cesium salts-mediated, scalable and solvent-free methodology to transform biosourced pyroglutamic acid and its derivatives to their N,N′-aminals, N,O,N,S-acetals and C5-substituted γ-lactams in good to excellent yields. This protocol is applicable to a large range of substrates, conducting to C5-substituted γ-lactam derivatives as potential new biologically active compounds.
coredata.dc:title: Cesium salts as superior catalysts for solvent-free modifications of biosourced pterolactam
